default: You start without any equipment. Any equipment granted by your background either exists in a place designated by the DM or is lost.

entries: When using the optional rule on multiclassing in the Player's Handbook (p. 163), the ghost class imposes no additional prerequisites and grants no proficiencies when taken after 1st level.

Lack of a body can make it difficult for a ghost to make use of other classes' features (see Spirit Form). To add a touch of the supernatural to your character while avoiding the obstacles posed by Spirit Form, consider using the Occultist Class Variant on page 12 of this document.

class.name: Occultist (Ghost Variant)

default: (a) a {@item scholar's pack|phb}, (b) a {@item explorer's pack|phb}

(a) a {@item Playing Card Set|phb|deck of playing or divining cards} or (b) an {@filter musical instrument|items|miscellaneous=mundane|type=instrument} or (c) an one set of {@filter artisan's tools|items|miscellaneous=mundane|type=artisan's tools}

entries: If your group uses the optional rule on multiclassing in the Player's Handbook, here's what you need to know if you choose occultist as one of your classes.

tools: any one type of {@item artisan's tools|PHB} of your choice

classFeatures: Shepherd Of The Lost Souls|Occultist (Ghost Variant)|JRRTG|20

classFeature.name: Spirit Form

entries: At 1st level, your mortal body has perished, but your spirit remains tethered to the Material Plane.

Your creature type is undead, you can't make attacks, and you can't cast spells using other classes' features. You can't interact with objects and equipment willingly, although creatures, traps, and other hazards can harm you normally. Your hit points can't be restored except by spending hit dice or completing a long rest, and you leave behind no body when you die.
You must obey the laws of physics and are slowed by difficult terrain as normal. Although your faltering tether can be a hindrance, it provides the following benefits:

items: You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks.
You have immunity to poison damage.
You are immune to the grappled, petrified, poisoned, prone, and restrained conditions.
You take no damage from falling.

entries: As a disembodied spirit, you no longer require air, food, drink, or sleep. You also gain abiding magical abilities:

items: {@i Ethereal Sight}: You can see into the {@i Ethereal Plane} within 30 feet of you.
You can cast {@spell thaumaturgy|PHB} at will, requiring no components.

entries: If a ghost class feature allows you to cast a spell, you do so at its lowest possible level. Your spellcasting ability is Charisma.
Some of your ghost class features require your target to make a saving throw to resist their effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

classFeature.name: Possession
entries: As an action, you can possess one willing humanoid you can see within 5 feet of you. A possessed creature is called your host. You then disappear and can only perceive your surroundings through the host's senses.

While possessing a host, you can't be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect, except ones that turn undead. You retain your alignment and game statistics, such as ability scores and class features, and maintain your position in initiative. The host can continue to act as normal, and you continue to take actions on your turn in combat.
Your host gains the following benefits while you possess them:

items: Your host benefits from your special senses, such as Ethereal Sight, and your language proficiencies, if any.
You can communicate with your host telepathically and vice versa.

Whenever your host makes an ability check with a skill or tool, an attack roll with a weapon, or a saving throw, you may roll a d4 and add the result to their roll's total if you have proficiency with that skill, tool, weapon, or saving throw.

entries: While possessing a host, you can only take actions granted by ghost class features. You also gain additional action options:

items: {@i Embolden}: As an action, you grant your host temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of 1). These hit points are lost when the possession ends.
{@i Harmonize}: As an action, you grant your host advantage on the next attack roll they make before the start of your next turn.

{@i Project}: As an action, you can use your Possession ability on a new target. When used in this way it has a range of 30 feet, and after changing hosts you can immediately take another action other than this one.

entries: If an effect requires you to target creatures or establish distances, do so as if you were in the host's space. If your host takes damage while you're concentrating on a spell, you must save to maintain concentration as if you'd taken the damage yourself.

The possession lasts until the host drops to 0 hit points, you possess a different creature, you end it as a bonus action, or you are turned or forced out by an effect like the dispel evil and good spell. Unless you're possessing a new host, you appear in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the host you vacated.

entries.name: Variant: Animal Forms
entries: Some ghosts appear in animal form, representing totem beasts or unusual familiars.

When you gain the Spirit Form ability at 1st level, you can designate one medium or smaller beast to represent you. You appear as the chosen creature, though you are spectral. Other than your size category, none of your game statistics change. Your creature type remains undead, and any capacity for flight is withheld until 15th level, when it is represented by Incorporeal Movement.

When using your abilities that possess a host, you may elect to remain visible: tucked in a pocket; circling overhead; wreathing them in an aura; or running alongside them. Regardless of your choice, the restrictions on the actions you can take and effects that can target you are the same.

classFeature.name: Unfinished Business
entries: Different ghosts have different reasons to linger in the mortal world. The unfinished business you choose reflects this purpose and the ends to which you guide your allies and hosts.

At 1st level, you choose an unfinished business that describes your agenda in the mortal world: Duty Not Done, Malice Unsated, Mischief Not Managed, or Restless Blade. Each unfinished business is detailed at the end of the class description. Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level, and additional benefits at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Unfinished Business
entries: Different ghosts have different reasons to linger in the mortal world. The unfinished business you choose reflects this purpose and the ends to which you guide your allies and hosts.

At 6th level, you choose an unfinished business that describes your agenda in the mortal world: Duty Not Done, Malice Unsated, Mischief Not Managed, or Restless Blade. Each unfinished business is detailed at the end of the class description. Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level, and additional benefits at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Unfinished Business
entries: Different ghosts have different reasons to linger in the mortal world. The unfinished business you choose reflects this purpose and the ends to which you guide your allies and hosts.

At 11th level, you choose an unfinished business that describes your agenda in the mortal world: Duty Not Done, Malice Unsated, Mischief Not Managed, or Restless Blade. Each unfinished business is detailed at the end of the class description. Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level, and additional benefits at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Unfinished Business
entries: Different ghosts have different reasons to linger in the mortal world. The unfinished business you choose reflects this purpose and the ends to which you guide your allies and hosts.

At 17th level, you choose an unfinished business that describes your agenda in the mortal world: Duty Not Done, Malice Unsated, Mischief Not Managed, or Restless Blade. Each unfinished business is detailed at the end of the class description. Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level, and additional benefits at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Insight
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your mystical premonitions allow you to better guide your allies and thwart your foes. You can cast {@spell augury|PHB}, requiring no components. When cast in this way, the reading simply becomes known to you, marked by a gust of chill wind, a distant birdcall, or some other supernatural phenomenon.
Once you cast {@spell augury|PHB} in this way, you must finish a short or long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Manifestations
entries: Drawing on the forces that sustain you, you've learned to manifest abiding magical abilities, twisting your spirit body to suit your needs.

At 3rd level, you gain a manifestation of your choice. Your manifestation options are detailed at the end of the class description. When you gain certain ghost levels, you gain additional manifestations of your choice, as shown in the {@filter Manifestations|optionalfeatures|feature type=OF:JRRTG} Known column of the {@filter Ghost table|spells|class=Ghost}.

Whenever you complete a long rest, you can choose one of the {@filter manifestations|optionalfeatures|feature type=OF:JRRTG} you know and replace it with another manifestation for which you meet the prerequisites.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Rejuvenation
entries: At 5th level, when you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can use your reaction to possess a willing humanoid within 30 feet of you. If you do, you become {@condition unconscious|PHB} but stable. Your host gains none of the usual benefits of your {@classFeature Possession|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} ability, and you become unstable again if the possession ends. After occupying a host for 1 hour, you regain 1 hit point, become {@condition conscious|PHB}, and the possession ends.

classFeature.name: Medium
entries: Just as you project your spirit body from host to host on the Material Plane, you've learned to cast a {@spell web|PHB} in the Border Ethereal, serving as a conduit between allies near and far.

As of 10th level you can cast {@spell Rary's telepathic bond|PHB} at will, requiring no components. Creatures connected in this way have advantage on saving throws to resist being {@condition charmed|PHB} or {@condition frightened|PHB}.

classFeature.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: By 15th level, you've learned not only to strengthen your grip on the Material Plane but also to weaken it, unshackling you from the harsh laws of reality.
You gain a flying speed of 40ft.

Additionally, when moving, you can pass through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. If you end your turn inside an object, you take {@damage 1d10} force damage and appear in the nearest unoccupied space.

classFeature.name: Journey's End
entries: At 20th level, you must decide whether to pass on to the next world or persist in this one. You gain one feature of your choice from the two below: {@classFeature Embrace the End|Ghost|JRRTG|20|JRRTG}, or {@classFeature Deny Reality's Rule|Ghost|JRRTG|20|JRRTG}.

classFeature.name: Embrace the End
entries: You are grateful for an afterlife well lived. Perhaps one last struggle stands between you and your final respite, or perhaps it's time to discover what the next world has in store.

After choosing this option at 20th level, you can pass on to the afterlife as an action (the effects of which are determined by the DM). Until you do so, you can draw on your enlightenment as an action, gaining the benefits of an {@spell augury|PHB} spell with no chance of a random reading.

classFeature.name: Deny Reality's Rule
entries: You reject the cruel hand dealt to you by fate, leaving your mortal origins and perhaps even your unfinished business far behind you.

After choosing this option at 20th level, you are no longer considered undead when determining which spells and abilities can target you. Thereafter, no magic, however powerful, can restore you to life.

Additionally, you can cast {@spell wish|PHB} once, requiring no components, and regain the ability to do so after 7 days. Should you suffer stress while casting {@spell wish|PHB} this way, you may nonetheless wish again, but only to duplicate the effects of an 8th level or lower spell.

entries.name: Second Chance
entries: A ghost character returned to life by magic such as {@spell true resurrection|PHB} or {@spell wish|PHB} immediately replaces their ghost class levels with levels in another class. Consider how the character's ordeal might have changed them. Is their unfinished business still what drives them, or has a second chance at life reordered their priorities?

classFeature.name: Channeler
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can call forth a lost soul from the Border Ethereal whenever you finish a long rest. This apparition uses your ability scores, has a base walking speed of 30 feet, and is proficient in your choice of any three skills, tools, or languages. It otherwise uses the statistics of a ghost character with no race or background, with as many levels in ghost as you have occultist.

You control the spirit, which takes its turn on your initiative. You choose how it behaves and moves, though it doesn't take actions unless you command it to. You can use your action to mentally command the spirit if it is within 120 feet of you. When you do, it can take actions appropriate to its game statistics until the start of your next turn. The spirit never requires your command to use its reaction. Until given its first command, the spirit you channel inhabits you using {@classFeature Possession|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG}.

If you die, the spirit vanishes. If you fall {@condition unconscious}, the spirit is incapacitated until you regain consciousness. If the spirit dies, you must make a Charisma save against its Ghost save DC, suffering 3 levels of exhaustion if you fail, or 1 if you pass. Whenever you finish a long rest, you can channel a different spirit, dismissing any others. When you do, you can choose different skills, tools, or languages for its 3 proficiencies.

If an occultist class feature 'replaces' a feature of a different name, the spirits you summon with Channeler don't gain that feature. Beginning at 3rd level in this class, you can choose the ghost's Manifestations whenever you summon it.

classFeature.name: Locus Of The Lost
entries: At 1st level, you choose the nature of the lost souls you channel and command.
Select an {@classFeature Unfinished Business|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} from the Ghost class feature of the same name: Duty Not Done, Malice Unsated, Mischief Not Managed, or Restless Blade.

The Unfinished Business you choose applies to every ghost summoned by your {@classFeature Channeler|Occultist (Ghost Variant)|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} feature. If your choice allows spirits to learn spells from the {@filter Ghost spell list|spells|class=Ghost}, choose them when you gain this feature and whenever you gain levels in this class. Every spirit you summon knows the same list of {@filter Ghost spells|spells|class=Ghost}.

classFeature.name: Personal Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Personal Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Personal Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Personal Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Personal Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Superior Medium
entries: By 10th level, you've learned to channel not only the restless dead, but also the tumultuous thoughts of the living.

You can cast {@spell Rary's telepathic bond|PHB} at will, requiring no components. Creatures connected in this way have advantage on saving throws to resist being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}. While connected by this bond, you can use your action to command a spirit regardless of the distance between you.

classFeature.name: Shepherd Of The Lost Souls
entries: At 20th level, you are a shining beacon to wandering spirits, able to grant reprieve to the restless dead. Spirits summoned by your {@classFeature Channeler|Occultist (Ghost Variant)|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} feature can take actions without being commanded (you still decide which actions they take).

Additionally, you can attempt to put lingering spirits to rest. As an action, you can soothe an undead creature you can see within 5 feet of you, even if the creature is on the {@i Ethereal Plane}. A willing target is immediately destroyed, allowing its soul, if any, to move on to the afterlife. An unwilling target makes a Charisma saving throw with a DC equal to its own Charisma score, dropping to 0 hit points on a fail, or becoming immune to this feature for 24 hours on a success. Undead that cannot be turned succeed on their saving throw automatically.

subclass.name: Mischief Not Managed
subclassFeatures: Dance Of The Departed|Ghost|JRRTG|Mischief Not Managed|JRRTG|6
The Show Goes On|Ghost|JRRTG|Mischief Not Managed|JRRTG|17

subclassFeature.name: Duty Not Done
entries: You strive to further a cause, uphold a virtue, or defend a person or place of sacred significance. Your uncanny magic protects and empowers your allies, hoping to do together what you couldn't alone.

subclassFeature.name: Augment
entries: When you choose this unfinished business at 1st level, and every time you gain a level in this class there after, you learn one spell of your choice from the {@filter Ghost spell list|spells|class=Ghost} (printed at the end of the class description).

items: A spell you choose must be of a level no higher than what's shown in the {@filter Ghost table's|spells|class=Ghost} {@i Supernatural Powers} column for your level.
You can only cast augment spells while possessing a host.
Augment spells with a range of self affect your host, not you. Otherwise, such spells target only your host regardless of their normal range.
Augment spells require no components, and all such spells end immediately if the possession ends.
You can cast a number of augment spells equal to your proficiency bonus.
You regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

entries: Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the augment spells you know and replace it with another spell from the {@filter Ghost spell list|spells|class=Ghost}, which must also be of a level no greater than your {@i Supernatural Powers} value.

subclassFeature.name: Aegis
entries: Starting at 6th level, whenever you take the Embolden action, you grant temporary hit points equal to your ghost level (instead of your Charisma modifier).
Additionally, if your host is reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, they immediately become stable. The possession then ends as normal.

subclassFeature.name: Otherworldly Guardian
entries: Starting at 11th level, a creature possessed by you is always under the effects of a {@spell protection from evil and good|PHB} spell.

subclassFeature.name: Unyielding Protector
entries: Starting at 17th level, your concentration on augment spells cannot be broken as a result of your host taking damage.
Additionally, whenever you roll for initiative, you regain one expended use of your Augment feature.

subclassFeature.name: Malice Unsated
entries: Your appetite for vengeance has gone unsatisfied, and you strive to bring harm to a hated foe, wreak havoc on an organization that wronged you, or repay a transgression in kind. You use hosts like puppets to achieve your goals, unable to pursue your agenda without mortal aid. Your {@i supernatural powers} can turn foes against one another and reanimate the fallen as pawns in your loathsome game.

subclassFeature.name: Malefic Possession
entries: Starting when you choose this unfinished business at 1st level, you can use your {@classFeature Possession|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} ability on unwilling creatures. An unwilling target can be of any creature type except undead and may make a Charisma saving throw to resist the effect. If it passes, the possession fails, and you remain wherever you were before the attempt.
An unwilling host gains none of the benefits of your {@classFeature Possession|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} ability. You gain the following action options while possessing an unwilling host:

items: {@i The Gibbering}: As an action, you force your host to make a Constitution saving throw. If they fail, they lose their concentration on spells, and can speak only in gibberish until the start of your next turn.
{@i Maddening Whispers}: As an action, you force your host to make a Wisdom saving throw. If they fail, they have disadvantage on attack rolls until the start of your next turn.

{@i Wrest Control}: As an action, you force your host to make a Charisma saving throw. If they fail, they behave as if affected by a confusion spell until the end of their next turn. You can't use Wrest Control again before the possession ends.

entries: An unwilling host can use its action to make a Charisma save. If it succeeds, the possession ends. The possession also ends if the host travels to a different plane of existence, leaving you behind. Once an unwilling possession ends, or after a target succeeds on the initial saving throw, you must finish a long rest before you can possess that creature again.
When an unwilling possession ends, you can use your reaction to possess a willing humanoid within 30 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Life Drain
entries: Starting at 1st level, when a creature you're possessing hits with a melee attack, you can cause the attack to deal additional necrotic damage. The extra damage is a number of d8 equal to your {@i Supernatural Powers} value, as shown in the {@filter Ghost table|spells|class=Ghost}. A creature dealt damage this way can't regain hit points until the end of its next turn.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Grim Puppeteer
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can possess the corpses of the slain. While not possessing a host, you can use your action to disappear into an intact corpse you can see within 5 feet of you. The corpse must be Large or smaller and be that of a beast or a humanoid. You are now effectively the possessed creature, which gains none of the benefits of your {@classFeature Possession|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} ability. Its type becomes undead, though it now looks alive, and it gains a number of temporary hit points equal to your hit point maximum.

While possessing a corpse, you maintain your alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and immunity to poison. You otherwise use the possessed target's game statistics, gaining access to its proficiencies, but not its class features, if any.

The possession lasts until the temporary hit points are lost (at which point the body becomes a corpse once more) or you end it as a bonus action. When the possession ends, you reappear in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the corpse.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Domineering Will
entries: By 11th level, you've grown strong enough to seize full control of unwilling hosts. While possessing an unwilling beast or humanoid, you gain the following action option:

items: {@i Subjugate}: As an action, you force your host to make a Charisma saving throw. If they succeed, the possession ends. If they fail, they are incapacitated, and you assume complete control of their body until the possession ends. On your turn, you may forgo your own movement and actions to manipulate the host. When you do, you can immediately make it move and perform actions appropriate to its game statistics. You don't gain access to the target's knowledge, nor class features, if any.

entries: Once a creature fails its saving throw against this effect, you must finish a long rest before you can use {@i Subjugate} again.

subclassFeature.name: Undying Hate
entries: Beginning at 17th level, whenever you roll for initiative, you regain all expended uses of your Life Drain feature.

Additionally, any creature dealt damage by your Life Drain has its hit point maximum reduced by the same amount. The reduction lasts until the creature finishes a long rest. The target dies if this reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

subclassFeature.name: Mischief Not Managed
entries: Not all who wander between worlds are grim spectres and dour phantoms. You linger to experience a thrill, pull off a heist, or entertain a loved one you couldn't while you were alive. Armed with a sense of humour uncommon amongst the dead, you regard your allies and hosts as accomplices in your supernatural pranks.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Of Discretion
entries: When you choose this unfinished business at 1st level, you gain proficiency in the Stealth skill.

subclassFeature.name: Poltergeist
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can cast {@spell catapult|XGE} and {@spell mage hand|PHB} at will, requiring no components. When cast in this way, the hand produced by {@i mage hand|PHB} is {@condition invisible}, and the damage dice of catapult are replaced with a number of {@dice 1d8} equal to your {@i Supernatural Powers} value, as shown in the {@filter Ghost table|spells|class=Ghost}.

subclassFeature.name: Beck And Call
entries: At 6th level, you gain proficiency in the Sleight of Hand skill (see {@classFeature Possession|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} for the benefits of proficiency).
Additionally, when you cast mage hand, you can perform the following additional tasks with it:

items: You can stow one object the hand is holding in a container worn or carried by another creature.
You can retrieve an object in a container worn or carried by another creature.

entries: You can perform one of these tasks without being noticed by a creature if you succeed on a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check contested by the creature's Wisdom (Perception) check.

subclassFeature.name: Dance Of The Departed
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can cast {@spell animate objects|PHB}, requiring no components. When cast in this way, you can animate a number of objects equal to your {@i Supernatural Powers} value (instead of ten), as shown in the Ghost table.
Once you cast {@spell animate objects|PHB} in this way, you must finish a short or long rest before you can do so again.

subclassFeature.name: Subtle Possession
entries: Beginning at 11th level, you can use your {@classFeature Possession|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} ability on unwilling creatures. An unwilling target can be of any creature type except undead and may make a Charisma saving throw to resist the effect. If it passes, the possession fails, and you remain wherever you were before the attempt. Pass or fail, the target must succeed at a Wisdom (Insight) check against your Ghost save DC to determine that anything is amiss.
An unwilling host gains none of the benefits of your {@classFeature Possession|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} ability. You gain the following action options while possessing an unwilling host:

items: {@i Delude}: You can cast phantasmal force, requiring no components. When cast in this way, the spell targets only your host, and ends early if the possession ends. You can't use Delude again before the possession ends.

{@i The Gibbering}: As an action, you force your host to make a Constitution saving throw. If they fail, they lose their concentration on spells, and can speak only in gibberish until the start of your next turn.
{@i Steal Thoughts}: You can cast detect thoughts, requiring no components. When cast in this way, the spell detects only your host, and ends early if the possession ends.

entries: An unsuspecting host can use its action to repeat the Insight check, deducing your presence on a success. The host becomes aware of you automatically if you force them to make a saving throw. An unwilling host that learns of your presence can use its action to make a Charisma save. If it succeeds, the possession ends. The possession also ends if the host travels to a different plane of existence, leaving you behind.

Once an unwilling possession ends, or after a target succeeds on the initial saving throw, you must finish a long rest before you can possess that creature again. When an unwilling possession ends, you can use your reaction to possess a willing humanoid within 30 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: The Show Goes On
entries: Starting at 17th level, whenever you roll for initiative, if your {@subclassFeature Dance Of The Departed|Ghost|JRRTG|Mischief Not Managed|JRRTG|6} feature has been expended, you immediately regain its use.
Additionally, you can cast telekinesis, requiring no components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you must finish a short or long rest before you can do so again.

subclassFeature.name: Restless Blade
entries: For some, death on the battlefield is the highest honor or final insult, for others, it is the first step on a path of endless conflict. You aim to train a successor, perfect a martial art, or overcome a monster that you couldn't in life, but your skills go to waste without hands that can wield a blade. You look to your allies and hosts to pursue your goals, sharing in their glory as you guide and protect them.

subclassFeature.name: One With Blade
entries: When you choose this unfinished business at 1st level, you gain proficiency with simple and martial weapons (see {@classFeature Possession|Ghost|JRRTG|1|JRRTG} for the benefits of weapon proficiency).

Additionally, whenever you take the {@i Harmonize} action, the attack you grant advantage to deals additional damage. The extra damage is a number of {@dice 1d8} equal to your {@i Supernatural Powers} value, as shown in the Ghost table. The damage type is the same as the attack's.

subclassFeature.name: Ephemeral Shield
entries: Starting at 1st level, when a creature you're possessing suffers damage that is less than your current hit points, you can take the damage instead by absorbing the blow into your spectral form. The host's resistances and immunities apply as usual, but the damage you take can't be reduced in any way. Other effects inflicted by the damage's source apply to your host as normal.

subclassFeature.name: Phantasmal Warrior
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you've learned to wreathe yourself in energy, allowing you to impact the world around you for a limited time. Doing so requires a bonus action, and immediately ends your possession if you're possessing a host.

For one minute, you gain temporary hit points equal to your hit point maximum. While you have these hit points, you can make attacks, and can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. While any of these hit points remain, your AC can't be less than 16, and you can interact with objects and equipment normally.

Your unarmed strikes in this state deal force damage, representing phantasmal blades, swiping claws, or other elements of your spectral appearance. In place of the normal damage die of your unarmed strike, you can roll a number of d6 equal to your Supernatural Powers value, as shown in the Ghost table.
After one minute, or when the last of these temporary hit points are lost but you are still conscious, you can use your reaction to possess a willing humanoid within 30 feet of you.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Otherworldly Champion
entries: Starting at 11th level, you can extend your phantasmal presence to surround your host, lending strength to their strikes and cladding them in your crackling aura like armor.

While possessing a creature, you can cast {@spell Tenser's transformation|XGE}, requiring no components. When cast in this way, the spell affects your host, not you, and ends early if the possession ends. Once you cast Tenser's transformation in this way, you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

subclassFeature.name: Deathless Defiance
entries: By 17th level, nothing can be done to stay your immortal wrath. Whenever you roll for initiative, if your {@subclassFeature Phantasmal Warrior|Ghost|JRRTG|Restless Blade|JRRTG|6} feature has been expended, you immediately regain its use.
Additionally, while in your phantasmal state, you are immune to the {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} conditions.

optionalfeature.name: Chill Of The Grave

otherSummary.entry: {@subclassFeature Mischief Not Managed|Ghost|JRRTG|Mischief Not Managed|JRRTG|1|} unfinished business

entries: While possessing a creature, you can cast {@spell hold monster|PHB}, targeting only your host. When cast in this way, the spell requires no components, and ends early if the possession ends.
Once you cast {@spell hold monster|PHB} in this way, you must finish a short or long rest before you can do so again.

optionalfeature.name: Cloak Of Sorrows
entries: If a creature hits your host with a melee attack while your host has temporary hit points from your {@i Embolden} action, the creature takes a number of {@damage 1d6} psychic damage equal to your {@i Supernatural Powers} value, as shown in the Ghost table.

optionalfeature.name: Ghostly Flicker
entries: While possessing a host, you can cast {@spell blade ward|PHB} at will, requiring no components. When cast in this way, the spell affects your host, not you, and ends early if the possession ends.

optionalfeature.name: Haunting Guise
entries: As an action, you can momentarily take on a horrifying appearance. Each non-undead creature within 30 feet of you that can see you or a creature you're possessing must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if they are within 30 feet of you, ending the effect on itself on a success. Your host, if any, is immune to this effect, and affected creatures treat them as the source of their fear.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

optionalfeature.name: Keening Wail
entries: As an action, you can release a haunting moan. Creatures within 10 feet of you that can hear you must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature that fails takes {@damage 2d6} psychic damage and has disadvantage on saving throws until the end of your next turn. Your host, if any, is unaffected.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you roll for initiative.

optionalfeature.name: Knot In The Weave
entries: While possessing a spellcaster, you can use your action to replenish some of their spent spell slots. When you do, your host can choose spell slots to recover with a combined level equal to or less than half your ghost level (rounded up). None of the recovered slots can be 6th level or higher. Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.
For example, if you're a 4th level ghost, your host can recover up to two levels' worth of spell slots. They can recover either a 2nd-level spell slot or two 1st-level spell slots.

optionalfeature.name: Knowledge From Beyond
entries: You can cast {@spell divination|PHB}, requiring no components, gleaning answers from the spirits of the beyond. After casting the spell in this way, you can choose one skill, tool, or language. For the next 10 minutes, you and any creature you're possessing have proficiency with the chosen skill, tool, or language.
Once you cast divination in this way, you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

optionalfeature.name: Knowledge From Within
entries: One foot in the otherworld lets you draw on experience far beyond your years. You may add your {@i Charisma modifier to the result of any Arcana, Nature, History, or Religion} check you make.

optionalfeature.name: One With The Mist
entries: While possessing a creature, you can cast {@spell invisibility|PHB} or {@spell gaseous form|PHB} targeting only your host. These spells end early if the possession ends. Alternatively, while not possessing a creature, you can cast {@spell misty step|PHB}. When cast in this way, these spells require no components.
After using this manifestation once, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

optionalfeature.name: Otherworldly Spark
entries: While possessing a willing creature, your host's attacks with nonmagical weapons are considered magical.
Additionally, you can cast {@spell elemental weapon|PHB}, requiring no components, targeting one weapon worn or carried by your host. The spell ends early if the possession ends.
Once you cast {@spell elemental weapon|PHB} in this way, you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

optionalfeature.name: Phantasmal Strike
entries: Be it with spectral blades, grasping tendrils, or raking claws, you've mastered {@filter manifestations|optionalfeatures|feature type=OF:JRRTG} with which to assault your foes. You can cast {@spell spiritual weapon|PHB} at will, requiring no components, and can attack with it despite your Spirit Form.

optionalfeature.name: Spectral Affinity
entries: You can spend 1 hour drawing a magic item within 5 feet of you into the Border Ethereal. The item then disappears or is subsumed into your spectral form.

Thereafter, you are considered to be wielding, wearing, or carrying the item as appropriate. If eligible, you can attune to the item while this process occurs. You can't affect an artifact or sentient item this way, and you can be bound to no more than 3 magic items at a time. The item appears at your feet if you die, or if you use an action to break your bond with it.

optionalfeature.name: Spirit Sight
entries: You can cast {@spell comprehend languages|PHB}, {@spell detect evil and good|PHB}, {@spell detect magic|PHB}, {@spell locate object|PHB}, and {@spell see invisibility|PHB}, requiring no components. You can do so a total number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of once) and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
While possessing a creature, you share the benefits granted by these spells with your host.

optionalfeature.name: Tear In The Veil
entries: You can cast {@spell etherealness|PHB}, requiring no components, targeting yourself, your host (if any), and up to three willing creatures within 10 feet of you.
Once you cast {@spell etherealness|PHB} in this way, you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

optionalfeature.name: Voice Of The Departed
entries: While not possessing a creature, you can cast {@spell speak with dead|PHB} at will. When cast in this way, the spell requires no material component, and has a range of touch.
Additionally, you automatically know when the corpse tells a lie (though you don't have the power to compel it to tell the truth).

entries.name: Ghost
entries: Shrouded in silver mist, a halfling slips past the guards and glides into the catacombs beyond. A voice whispers in her ear, warning her of danger, while lights only she can see lead the way to a hidden sepulchre.

Eyes ablaze with soul-flame, a dark elf hurtles into the press of melee, their grasp drawing the life from all they touch. A voice whispers in their ear, spurring them on to ever greater violence, seeming to grow louder with every kill.

A human grips a shortsword with both hands, knuckles whitening as the enemy rush toward him. When all seems lost, a whisper in his ear imparts a lifetime of battle experience. Unseen hands reshape his posture, and he lunges to meet the foe with a master's poise.

The ghost isn't the halfling, the drow, or the human, but the whisper in their ears: the companion presence that empowers and shepherds them. Ghosts are united as a class by their disembodied forms and defined by their unfinished business in the mortal world. Some are vengeful, seeking to satisfy a malice unquenched in a single lifetime. Others are benign, defending those who carry on their work. Though sometimes a hindrance, a ghost's weak tether to the mortal world grants them paranormal power and insight. Their abilities can wreathe allies in protective magic, possess or dominate their foes, or pass on skills they learned in former lifetimes.

entries.name: One foot in the grave
entries: Warriors dishonored on the battlefield; commoners killed in cold blood; mentors who outlived their students; thieves who died behind bars plotting one last heist. Unable to find rest, ghosts are lost souls tied to the Border Ethereal. Some appear as spectral adventurers, replete with the tools of their trade. Others present as animals, or in abstract forms representing their personalities.

Ghosts bring a little of the otherworld with them when they return to the Material Plane. In time, they learn to harness the forces that sustain them, finding new ways to bend reality and assail their foes.

Through possession, ghosts are able to merge with and manipulate mortals. Though some are malicious and domineering, most go in search of companions who will heed their counsel. If a ghost and their host work in harmony, they can overcome obstacles neither could surmount alone.

entries.name: Undying Purpose
entries: Ghosts linger to see their unfinished business done, and the way their powers manifest reflects this task. Most met with untimely deaths, their origins steeped in tragedy. Others had duties unattainable in a single lifetime, such as guarding a relic or defending a certain bloodline. Such a soul might forgo their rest until a worthy successor is found, or serve as guardian to several generations of descendants. The beneficiaries of such protection should count themselves lucky, for a ghost's insight alone can avert disaster.

Half-trapped outside reality, ghosts depend on their allies to pursue their goals. Trustworthy companions are hard to find and these bonds, once forged, can last lifetimes. Unconstrained by time, a ghost might spend decades mentoring such a charge. Others might hunt artifacts or study occult lore: anything to avoid repeating their mortal failures.

entries.name: Creating a Ghost
entries: Creating a ghost character demands a backstory dominated by an extraordinary event: your death. Perhaps your demise itself began your unfinished business and you've sworn revenge against the villain that laid you low. Perhaps your passing was simply an obstacle on the road to a wider goal: the mastery of magic; the perfection of a martial art; or the appointment of a worthy successor to an ancient task.

What's your relationship like with your adventuring companions? Did they stumble across the relic you guard and take it with them, or is a member of their company the beneficiary of an old accord? Perhaps you were one of their number to begin with, and you linger to finish the adventure that claimed your life? Is one party member in particular your chosen champion, or do you consider the entire group your flock?

entries.name: Ghostly Encore
entries: When a player character dies with unfinished business, the DM may allow them to forgo their rest, replacing one or more of their class levels with levels in ghost. Consider letting a character with a low Charisma modifier substitute their Intelligence or Wisdom when using ghost class features.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a ghost quickly by following these suggestions. First, Charisma should be your highest ability score, followed by Constitution. If you plan to select the {@i Mischief Not Managed} unfinished business, make Dexterity your second-best score instead. Next, choose the {@background Variant Noble (Knight)|PHB} or {@background Variant Noble (Retainers)|PHB}, and take the variant feature: Retainers.

entries.name: Quirks and Foibles
entries: Consider adding some flourishes to make your ghost character stand out. The section below contains a few ideas. You can roll dice to determine traits randomly, pick those you fancy, or use the suggestions as inspiration for your own designs.

entries.name: Signature Phenomenon
entries: Every ghost has a tell-tale manifestation that they can't control: strange sounds, creeping chills, or sensations of profound loneliness or giddy excitement.

rows: A distant melody, tuneful birdcall, or fragment of nursery rhyme is carried on the wind around me.
Nearby pools and mirrors reflect older, more decrepit versions of those viewing them.
Animals sense when I'm close: cats hiss, dogs bark, and insects swarm without provocation.
I'm accompanied by gusts of chill wind or a warm summer breeze. Candles gutter and go out as I approach.
Hoarfrost creeps over nearby objects when I stand still.
Flowers blossom in my presence, but rapidly wither away when I move on.

entries.name: Untimely Demise
entries: As often as not, ghosts' origins are steeped in tragedy. What was the cause of your untimely passing, and how does the way you died affect your demeanor?

rows: My body lies broken alongside countless others on a forgotten battlefield.
I died in my sleep near the end of my natural lifespan, but until I appoint a successor I'll never rest.
I can't even remember how I died, and I'm not entirely sure I want to know.
Not even I survived the villain that slew my people, but that won't stop me from taking revenge.
Dead? I'm not dead! How could we possibly be talking if I was dead?!
I died in an embarrassing mundane accident, so I make up a different story whenever I'm asked.

entries.name: Possession Quirk
entries: Willing hosts help anchor ghosts to the mortal world, and ghosts repay this trust with counsel and protection. Though few would choose a battle of wills over earnest cooperation, most can't help but influence their hosts, allowing their personalities to overspill, or lacking complete control of their spirit bodies.
The following might apply to your hosts while you possess them. Make sure other players are comfortable using these traits: even if you possess them, it's their decision whether or not to play along.

rows: hoard objects that the ghost possessing me desires, such as coins, dice, wands, or holy symbols.
Even sat by a roaring campfire and dressed in the thickest coat, I never feel warm.
I just can't help myself around good food: everything tastes like I've never tried it before!
I'm terrified of an implement that was involved in the death of the ghost possessing me.
Whether doing something for the first time or the hundredth, I experience vivid flashes of déjà vu.
I sometimes unwittingly speak in the language of the ghost possessing me, bewildering my fellow adventures.

entries: As a ghost, you gain the following class features.

entries.name: Occultist (Ghost Variant)

entries: This variant represents a spiritualist, medium, or paranormal proxy. Occultists guide spirits but are themselves alive. The occultist can be played as a standalone class, or used in conjunction with the multiclassing rules in the Player's Handbook

Whether you're a commoner haunted by a loved one lost too soon, an adventurer beset by poltergeists, or a dedicated student of occult magic, you can call forth spirits from the Border Ethereal and commune with them.

entries.name: Speaker for Lost Soul
entries: Some occultists are pragmatic in their study, conjuring spirits to draw on their expertise. Others are empathic, listening for guidance from spirits who share their plight. Some are shamanic, mentored by nature spirits, while others unwittingly channel the dead, believing themselves haunted, unaware of their gifts.

What's your relationship like with the spirits you channel? Do they enter your service of their own volition, or are they bound to you, hoping to misconstrue your orders and slip their bonds? Perhaps you've struck a bargain with one lost soul, pursuing their unfinished business in return for aid? Is a particular spirit your tutor, such as a fallen comrade or totem animal, or do you seek guidance from a different soul each day?

rows: I answered the call to adventure after a loved one's death. Now, their spirit accompanies me on my perilous journey.
I channel the soul of an old enemy, suppressing their malice and guiding them toward redemption.
I'm haunted by one or more spirits that never speak to me. Interpreting their cryptic omens is my full-time job, and I fear their displeasure should I misconstrue them.
Every night, I'm contacted by a different spirit from the local area, hoping I'll channel them and revisit their old haunts.
I'm completely unaware of the spirit that guards me, mistaking its intervention for strokes of luck, or believing I have my own magical powers.
I spend hours meditating on the natural world, and animal spirits appear to me offering guidance.
A brush with death left me stood with one foot in the grave. Suddenly able to see spirits, I use my newfound abilities to help lost souls with their unfinished business.
A crime in my past drew the eye of a malicious spirit, which tempts me with power to continue its dark work.
